docs.lead_paragraph: ''It was a tough year in terms of big shoes to fill, you know?'' said Bruce Greenwood. ''President Kennedy's size 400 loafers sitting there on your desktop, and then Joseph Cotten's right beside them.'' Mr. Greenwood plays the president and enduring icon in ''13 Days,'' a dramatization of the Cuban missile crisis that goes into wide release today after its Oscar-qualifying runs in New York and Los Angeles over the holidays. And he will soon be seen in ''The Magnificent Ambersons,'' an A&E mini-series based on the original screenplay of Orson Welles's mangled masterpiece, in which Mr. Greenwood takes over Cotten's role as a well-intentioned Midwestern industrialist.

docs.lead_paragraph: The merger of Time-Warner and AOL, the rise of digital cinema, the dip in diversity on film and television, the Senate hearings on movie marketing, and the ''watershed'' combination of global storytelling techniques in Ang Lee's ''Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon'' were chosen as ''moments of significance'' in the American Film Institute's first attempt to chart the coming century in movies. The A.F.I., a nonprofit organization best known for its annual Lifetime Achievement Award, entered the movie awards fray this year by launching an annual Top 10 list and choosing ''moments of significance'' in the world of film. The choices are made by an annually rotating jury of a dozen filmmakers, scholars and critics whose identities were kept secret until the list was announced today.

docs.lead_paragraph: THE HIDING PLACE By Trezza Azzopardi 282 pages. Atlantic Monthly Press. $24. For the sisters in Trezza Azzopardi's new novel, one of the few bright spots in their bleak childhood comes when their father buys them several pet rabbits. But then one by one the bunnies begin disappearing. ''My father killed every single one, for food, for sport, for no reason at all,'' the narrator, Dolores, recalls. ''Like a poacher, he used them as a stake; he would take them out of his donkey jacket and throw their soft bodies on the counter of the betting shop. They were currency, and he spent them all.''

docs.lead_paragraph: Three Major League Soccer teams are feverishly at work in the off-season. The Los Angeles Galaxy and D.C. United are preparing for the Concacaf Champions Cup tournament, which will be played in Los Angeles starting next week. The Tampa Bay Mutiny is practicing for its exhibition against the Glasgow Celtic in Tampa on Jan. 19. The rest of the teams start training camp Feb. 1, with the MetroStars going to Portugal for training and exhibition games a week later. The Galaxy will play Real Espana of Honduras and D.C. United will meet Alajuelense of Costa Rica on Jan. 17, a day after Toluca of Mexico plays Olimpia of Honduras and Pachuca of Mexico meets Joe Public of Trinidad and Tobago. By the time it plays Espana, the Galaxy will most likely have Alexi Lalas under contract. The former member of the national team, who has decided to come out of retirement, wants to play for the Galaxy.

docs.lead_paragraph: SIDNEY LUMET sits in a control booth inside a truck stationed alongside the Kaufman Astoria Studios in Queens. Instead of imagining how the scene before him will look on the big screen, Mr. Lumet, the director of ''The Pawnbroker'' and ''Serpico,'' faces a bank of video monitors, judging how his latest sequence will play within the confines of a television set. After 42 films and five Academy Award nominations, the 76-year-old Mr. Lumet is serving as executive producer and principal director of a courtroom drama called ''100 Centre Street,'' which will have its premiere on A&E on Jan. 15. Conventional wisdom has it that a move from film to television is a step down the professional ladder. And it's true that Mr. Lumet probably wouldn't be making the transition if his movie career were still flourishing the way it was in the 60's and 70's. But he had another reason for taking on a small-screen project at this point: he was looking forward to returning to his roots.
docs.abstract: David Everitt profile of Sidney Lumet, veteran film director, who learned his craft in television in early 1950's and is returning to small screen as executive producer and principal director of 100 Centre Street, A&E courtroom drama; photo (M)

docs.snippet: HIRAM BINGHAM was not looking for Machu Picchu when he found it. When Bingham, an ambitious Yale archaeologist and future United States senator, led his mule train through the dense jungles of the Peruvian Andes in July 1911, he was searching for ...
docs.lead_paragraph: HIRAM BINGHAM was not looking for Machu Picchu when he found it. When Bingham, an ambitious Yale archaeologist and future United States senator, led his mule train through the dense jungles of the Peruvian Andes in July 1911, he was searching for Vilcabamba, a legendary stronghold of Inca resistance against Spanish rule. One morning, in exchange for a silver dollar, a local innkeeper agreed to show the explorer some ruins on top of a mountain called Machu Picchu. He guided Bingham across a set of wooden logs precariously positioned above the swollen Urubamba River. Then the pair climbed up a steep embankment, with the American at times barely holding on. By noon, Bingham was exhausted and not particularly eager to press on.
